How do you test that your postcondition is correct?

sqrt is the typical example for dbc because the postcondition is trivial. 
Without beeing a DBC guru I have the feeling that sometimes the postcondition is
in fact writing the reverse method.  For example:

   // returns the first position of the value in the array
   int firstPos(int[] array, int value) {
       int result = 0;
       for (int i=0; i<array.length; i++) {
          if (array[i] = value)
              result = i;
       }
       
       /* postcondition */
       assert(result >=0 && result < array.length);
       for (int i=0; i<result; i++) {
          assert(array[i] != value);
       }
   }

So maintaining the postcondition can be as difficult as writing the method
itself.  But I'm not a DBC guru.

I think that you could successfully used DBC and unit testing together.  Using
DBC doesn't imply that you don't unit test the code (idem for the contrary).

I'm sure that code using DBC have also bugs, that's why I'm not convinced (yet)
that DBC is the _only_ method.  Just one of many.
